etymology.description: 㚔 “handcuffs” + 𠬝 “to subdue” — to convict; to punish; to declare guilty.
etymology.interpretation: Imagery of shackles combined with subduing evokes judging and imposing a verdict, which naturally extends to publicly declaring information. From the notion of assigning due consequences comes the sense of repaying or returning in kind.
etymology.simplification: Simplified from 報 by replacing 幸 with 扌 (“hand”), reducing strokes and regularizing the verb/action radical; officially adopted in 1956.

examples.chinese: 我每天看报(我每天看報)。
examples.english: I read the newspaper every day.

examples.chinese: 他向领导报告了最新情况(他向領導報告了最新情況)。
examples.pinyin: Tā xiàng lǐngdǎo bàogào le zuìxīn qíngkuàng.
examples.english: He reported the latest situation to the leader.

examples.chinese: 以善报善，以恶报恶(以善報善，以惡報惡)。
examples.pinyin: Yǐ shàn bàoshàn, yǐ è bào’è.
examples.english: Repay good with good and evil with evil.
